MimiC: Combating Client Dropouts in Federated Learning by Mimicking Central Updates

Yuchang Sun, , Yuyi Mao, , and Jun Zhang Y. Sun and J. Zhang are with the Department of Electronic and Computer Engineering, The Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Hong Kong, China (E-mail: yuchang.sun@connect.ust.hk, eejzhang@ust.hk). Y. Mao is with the Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, The Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong, China (E-mail: yuyi-eie.mao@polyu.edu.hk).(Corresponding author: Yuyi Mao.) Manuscript received 23 June 2023; revised 19 September and 13 November 2023; accepted 20 November 2023. This work was supported by the Hong Kong Research Grants Council under the Areas of Excellence scheme grant AoE/E-601/22-R and NSFC/RGC Collaborative Research Scheme grant CRS_HKUST603/22.
Abstract

Federated learning (FL) is a promising framework for privacy-preserving collaborative learning, where model training tasks are distributed to clients and only the model updates need to be collected at a server. However, when being deployed at mobile edge networks, clients may have unpredictable availability and drop out of the training process, which hinders the convergence of FL. This paper tackles such a critical challenge. Specifically, we first investigate the convergence of the classical FedAvg algorithm with arbitrary client dropouts. We find that with the common choice of a decaying learning rate, FedAvg may oscillate around a stationary point of the global loss function in the worst case, which is caused by the divergence between the aggregated and desired central update. Motivated by this new observation, we then design a novel training algorithm named MimiC, where the server modifies each received model update based on the previous ones. The proposed modification of the received model updates mimics the imaginary central update irrespective of dropout clients. The theoretical analysis of MimiC shows that divergence between the aggregated and central update diminishes with proper learning rates, leading to its convergence. Simulation results further demonstrate that MimiC maintains stable convergence performance and learns better models than the baseline methods.

Index Terms:
Federated learning (FL), client dropout, straggler effect, edge intelligence, convergence analysis.

1 Introduction

The resurgence of deep learning (DL) intensifies the demand for training high-quality models from distributed data sources. However, the traditional approach of centralized model training may raise severe concerns of privacy leakage, since data, possibly with personal and sensitive information, need to be collected by a server prior to training. As a result, federated learning (FL) [1, 2], which is a privacy-preserving distributed model training paradigm, has recently received enormous attention [3, 4, 5, 6]. A typical FL system consists of a central server and many clients with private data, which collaborate to accomplish an iterative training process. In each training iteration, clients train local models based on their local data and upload the model updates to the server. Upon receiving the model updates, the server performs model aggregation and the aggregated global model is disseminated to clients for the next training iteration.

Depending on the types of clients, FL systems can be categorized as the cross-device and cross-silo settings [7]. In this work, we focus on cross-device FL [2, 8] where clients are usually edge devices (e.g., smartphones and wearables) with a relatively small volume of local data. Cross-device FL fits well with the new era of pervasive artificial intelligence (AI) [9, 10], which utilizes the distributed computational resources for real-time and cost-effective big data analytics. Note that clients of cross-device FL may have heterogeneous resources such as computing power, battery capacity, and network quality [11, 12]. Therefore, they may occasionally drop out of the training process for some iterations because of various unpredictable events, which is termed as client dropout. For example, mobile devices may run out of battery or be disconnected from the server. In such cases, only a subset of clients are able to complete local training and upload the model updates in each training iteration, which significantly degrades the convergence performance and training speed [13].

The problem of client dropout has been tackled in the context of distributed learning, where a model training task is intensionally divided and allocated to multiple computing nodes (i.e., clients) by a server. To guarantee satisfactory learning performance, the global dataset is usually partitioned such that training data on clients are independent and identically distributed (IID) in distributed learning. However, while a small fraction of dropout clients can be tolerated with IID training data, significant dropouts severely impair the training efficiency and slow down the convergence speed. Techniques such as coded computing [14, 15] and using backup clients [16] combat dropouts in distributed learning by redistributing training data and assigning redundant training tasks to clients. Nevertheless, client dropouts in FL cause some critical and unique challenges. Firstly, the local data on clients are non-IID. The non-IIDness cannot be mitigated since the local data are not allowed to be transferred to other clients or the server because of privacy concerns. Also, simply ignoring the inactive clients leads to a biased global update in each training iteration. In other words, if some clients drop out, the aggregated update will be biased towards the training data of the successful clients and thereby deviates from global training objective, which degrades the learned model performance [17, 18]. Fig. 1 shows a simple cross-device FL system with five clients to illustrate this issue, where we assume there are ten classes of data samples in total, but each client has only four classes of data. We observe that when clients 2 and 5 drop out, the aggregated update fails to exploit the information about classes 4 and 5.

It is worth noting that client dropout is different from active client sampling [19, 20, 21], as the latter assumes the server is able to select a portion of clients to participate in each training iteration. This is plausible due to an implicit premise that all the clients are available to be selected. However, if some selected clients drop out of training unexpectedly, the server can only aggregate the received updates and obtain a biased update that deviates from the desired global gradient. One possible approach to deal with client dropouts in cross-device FL is to use the memorized latest updates as a substitute for those dropout clients [22, 23]. Nevertheless, when some clients have been inactive for a long time, the global model may have changed substantially and thus the memorized updates suffer from strong staleness. In contrast, the deviation of each local update from the central one is primarily determined by the difference between the local and global training objectives. Since the objective bias should not change, intuitively the deviation of each update remains relatively stable throughout the training process, as will be explained in Section 5. As such, we aim to utilize such deviation to correct the individual updates from clients and mimic a central update.

In this paper, we investigate the impacts of arbitrary client dropouts on the convergence performance of FL and propose an effective approach to combat such negative impacts. Our main contributions are summarized as follows:

  • •

    We first investigate the convergence performance of the classical FedAvg algorithm [1] with arbitrary client dropouts. The theoretical analysis shows that client dropouts introduce a biased update in each training iteration. With the common choice of a decaying learning rate, the model learned by FedAvg may oscillate around a stationary point of the global loss function in the worst case.

  • •

    To combat client dropouts, we propose a novel FL algorithm named MimiC. The core idea of MimiC is augmenting each received update from the active clients to mimic an imaginary central update. Specifically, each received update is modified by a correction variable derived from previous iterations. This can be easily implemented at the server and introduces no additional computation or communication workload to clients.

  • •

    Despite the modified update in MimiC still being a biased estimate of the global gradient, we prove that its divergence is bounded and diminishes to zero with a proper choice of the learning rates. We further characterize the convergence of MimiC by imposing a mild assumption on the maximum number of consecutive client dropout iterations. It is also shown that MimiC converges with a high probability when clients drop out in a probabilistic pattern.

  • •

    To verify the analysis and test the effectiveness of our proposed algorithm, we simulate a cross-device FL system with a variety of client dropout patterns. The extensive experimental results validate the convergence of MimiC with client dropouts in different scenarios. It is also observed that MimiC consistently produces better models than the baseline methods.

Organizations. The rest of this paper is organized as follows. In Section 2, we introduce the related works. In Section 3, we describe the system model and setup of the cross-device FL problem. We analyze the convergence behavior of FedAvg and show the negative impacts of arbitrary client dropouts in Section 4. To combat client dropouts, we propose a training algorithm named MimiC in Section 5 and demonstrate its convergence in Section 6. The proposed algorithm is evaluated via extensive simulations in Section 7. Finally, we conclude the paper in Section 8.

2 Related Works

In this section, we review the exiting works on two research directions of FL that are closely related to our current study, including: 1) cross-device FL with partial client participation; and 2) techniques combating client dropouts in distributed and federated learning.

Cross-device FL with partial client participation. The cross-device FL systems usually consist of a large number of clients and only a fraction of them are able to participate in the training process at each iteration due to the limited communication and computational resources [7, 13, 24]. To ensure model convergence, there are two popular client sampling strategies, including: 1) to sample clients with replacement with respect to preset probabilities; 2) to sample clients without replacement uniformly at random. These strategies guarantee that the weighted sum of the sampled clients’ objectives is an unbiased estimate of the global training objective. However, in realistic applications, it is hard to implement these strategies due to arbitrary client dropouts, which makes the training objective biased in the presence of non-IID data.

Recently, Ruan et al. [25] investigated the convergence performance of FedAvg with strongly convex loss functions in practical scenarios where clients have various participating behaviors. Specifically, the clients are allowed to have various local steps in each training iteration and those clients with a local step of zero can be viewed as dropout clients. It is shown that by controlling the aggregation weights FedAvg with client dropouts can still converge to the global optimum, which, however, required the prior knowledge of client participation probabilities. Besides, a unified convergence analysis for FL with arbitrary client participation was provided in [26], where the accumulated model updates in every H𝐻H training iterations are adopted as momentum to accelerate the global model training. It was shown that the arbitrary client participation introduces an additional term δ~2​(H)superscript~𝛿2𝐻\tilde{\delta}^{2}(H) in the convergence bound, which can be eliminated only if the client participation pattern, the amplification period H𝐻H, and the aggregations weights satisfy certain conditions, e.g., regularized participation or ergodic participation. In practice, these conditions are difficult to verify and need laborious hyperparameter tuning. In addition, another thread of works [24, 27] designed various client sampling strategies to accelerate the convergence rate of FL. These works, however, are beyond the scope of this paper, since they assume clients can be actively selected to participate in the training process.

Combating client dropouts in distributed and federated learning. In distributed learning, client dropouts can be handled via coded computing [14, 28], which carefully designs the training tasks on clients to introduce some levels of redundancy, such that the dropout clients can no longer cause fatal effects on training. However, these methods either assume IID data or require to redistribute the training data among clients, which may be contradictory to the privacy-preserving principle of FL. Motivated by coded computing for distributed learning, recent works [29, 30] proposed to construct coded datasets at clients, which are then transmitted to the server or other clients to compensate for the missing model updates of dropout clients. Nevertheless, coded data transmission may bring additional communication overhead and be risky of privacy leakage. Similarly, [31, 32] resorted to Shamir’s secret sharing for the coded data, which retains the privacy protection of conventional FL. However, the substantial communication overhead in these designs is intolerable especially with thousands of clients in cross-device FL systems [7].

In addition to coded computing techniques, some other strategies can be adopted to combat client dropouts in FL. The simplest strategy of combating client dropouts in FL is to only aggregate the received updates. This passive approach, however, significantly deteriorates the convergence performance due to the biased aggregated update. Besides, another strategy is to adopt the latest updates from inactive clients as substitutes [22, 23]. Nevertheless, the memorized updates with significant staleness may degrade the training performance in the current iteration. Alternatively, the local update from another client with similar data can be used as substitute for that of a dropout client [33]. However, this approach requires to compute the pair-wise similarity between any two clients, which leads to a high computation cost. We also notice that there is another line of studies [34, 35] on privacy-preserving schemes for cross-device FL with client dropouts. Specifically, to achieve a target level of differential privacy (DP) in FL with random client dropouts, Jiang et al. [34] designed an “add-then-remove” approach to determine the noise levels of local gradients. Moreover, a privacy-preserving aggregation scheme for FL was proposed in [35], which is resilient to client dropouts with the aid of Shamir’s secret sharing. However, these works have not implemented any mechanism to compensate the missing model updates of dropout clients and still suffer from degraded model performance.

3 System Model and Problem Setup

We consider a cross-device FL system consisting of a central server and N𝑁N clients (denoted by the set 𝒩={1,…,N}𝒩1…𝑁\mathcal{N}=\{1,\dots,N\}). These nodes collaboratively train a model 𝐰∈ℝM𝐰superscriptℝ𝑀\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{M} with M𝑀M trainable parameters to minimize the loss over data samples of all clients. The global training objective is expressed as follows:

min𝐰∈ℝM⁡f​(𝐰)=1N​∑i=1Nfi​(𝐰),subscript𝐰superscriptℝ𝑀𝑓𝐰1𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰\min_{\mathbf{w}\in\mathbb{R}^{M}}f(\mathbf{w})=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}f_{i}(\mathbf{w}), (1)

where fi​(𝐰)subscript𝑓𝑖𝐰f_{i}(\mathbf{w}) denotes the i𝑖i-th client’s loss function over the local dataset 𝒟isubscript𝒟𝑖\mathcal{D}_{i}.

To optimize model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}, the classical FedAvg [1] algorithm divides the training process of model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w} into T𝑇T iterations. In iteration t∈[T]𝑡delimited-[]𝑇t\in[T], clients receive a global model 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t} from the server and train the model locally for K𝐾K steps using the mini-batch SGD algorithm. Specifically, the local model is initialized as 𝐰t,0i≡𝐰t,∀i∈𝒩formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡0𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡for-all𝑖𝒩\mathbf{w}_{t,0}^{i}\equiv\mathbf{w}_{t},\forall i\in\mathcal{N}. Since a client may own a considerable amount of training data, it is impractical to compute the gradient over the whole dataset for local training. Thus, client i𝑖i samples a batch of data ξ𝜉\xi and computes gradient ∇Fi​(𝐰;ξ)∇subscript𝐹𝑖𝐰𝜉\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w};\mathbf{\xi}) based on the current model 𝐰𝐰\mathbf{w}. At the k𝑘k-th local step, the client uniformly samples a batch of training data ξt,kisuperscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝑘𝑖\mathbf{\xi}_{t,k}^{i}, and updates the model 𝐰t,kisuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘𝑖\mathbf{w}_{t,k}^{i} as follows:

𝐰t,k+1i←𝐰t,ki−ηL​∇Fi​(𝐰t,ki;ξt,ki),k=0,1,…,K−1,formulae-sequence←superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘1𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘𝑖subscript𝜂𝐿∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝑘𝑖𝑘01…𝐾1\mathbf{w}_{t,k+1}^{i}\leftarrow\mathbf{w}_{t,k}^{i}-\eta_{L}\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t,k}^{i};\mathbf{\xi}_{t,k}^{i}),k=0,1,\dots,K\!-\!1, (2)

where ηLsubscript𝜂𝐿\eta_{L} denotes the local learning rate. The local update after K𝐾K local steps is summarized as follows:

g^i​(𝐰t)≜1K​∑k=0K−1∇Fi​(𝐰t,ki;ξt,ki),≜subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡1𝐾superscriptsubscript𝑘0𝐾1∇subscript𝐹𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘𝑖superscriptsubscript𝜉𝑡𝑘𝑖\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})\triangleq\frac{1}{K}\sum_{k=0}^{K-1}\nabla F_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t,k}^{i};\mathbf{\xi}_{t,k}^{i}), (3)

which is then uploaded to the server.

In each iteration, we assume that only a subset of clients 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}_{t} is active for training, which are denoted as active clients. Others are dropout clients (i.e., inactive clients) that fail in either local training or gradient uploading. The server only receives model updates from the active clients in 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}_{t}. Afterwards, the global update is computed as an average of them as follows:

𝐯t≜1|𝒮t|​∑i∈𝒮tg^i​(𝐰t).≜subscript𝐯𝑡1subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{v}_{t}\triangleq\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}_{t}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}). (4)

The global model is then updated using the global learning rate ηtsubscript𝜂𝑡\eta_{t} as follows:

𝐰t+1←𝐰t−ηt​𝐯t.←subscript𝐰𝑡1subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐯𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t+1}\leftarrow\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta_{t}\mathbf{v}_{t}. (5)

This new global model 𝐰t+1subscript𝐰𝑡1\mathbf{w}_{t+1} is broadcast to all clients for the next training iteration.

In the training process, each client may remain inactive for several consecutive training iterations. We introduce the notation of τ​(t,i)𝜏𝑡𝑖\tau(t,i), which indicates client i𝑖i has been inactive for τ​(t,i)−1𝜏𝑡𝑖1\tau(t,i)-1 consecutive iterations, i.e., the last iteration of client i𝑖i being active before iteration t𝑡t is t−τ​(t,i)𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖t-\tau(t,i) [23, 22]. Fig. 2 provides an illustration of the client availability in cross-device FL systems.

Assumption 1.

(Client availability) There exists a constant τmax>0subscript𝜏max0\tau_{\text{max}}>0 such that τ​(t,i)≤τmax,∀i∈𝒩,t∈[T]formulae-sequence𝜏𝑡𝑖subscript𝜏maxformulae-sequencefor-all𝑖𝒩𝑡delimited-[]𝑇\tau(t,i)\leq\tau_{\text{max}},\forall i\in\mathcal{N},t\in[T].

In the next section, we analyze the convergence performance of FedAvg and show the negative effect of arbitrary client dropouts on its convergence.

4 Theoretical Analysis of FedAvg with Arbitrary Client Dropouts

The convergence of FedAvg, under the assumption of full client participation or uniform partial participation, has been presented in [38, 39, 20]. Specifically, if the global learning rates are selected as ηt≡𝒪​(1T)subscript𝜂𝑡𝒪1𝑇\eta_{t}\equiv\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right), FedAvg is guaranteed to converge to a stationary point of the global loss function with a rate of 𝒪​(1T)𝒪1𝑇\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\sqrt{T}}\right). However, these convergence results rely on strict assumptions of client availability, which ensures an unbiased estimate of the global gradient at the server, i.e.,

𝔼​[𝐯t]=𝔼𝒮t​[1|𝒮t|​∑i∈𝒮tg^i​(𝐰t)]=1|𝒩|​∑i∈𝒩g^i​(𝐰t).𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐯𝑡subscript𝔼subscript𝒮𝑡delimited-[]1subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡1𝒩subscript𝑖𝒩subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{v}_{t}]=\mathbb{E}_{\mathcal{S}_{t}}\left[\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}_{t}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right]=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{N}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}). (6)

Since client dropouts are spontaneous and uncontrollable, (6) can hardly be achieved in practice. In this section, we investigate the convergence behavior of FedAvg in the presence of arbitrary client dropouts, which relaxes the assumption of full or uniform partial participation.

To proceed, we first derive an upper bound of the loss decay in each training iteration in Lemma 1, which is applicable to any FL algorithm satisfying the global update scheme in (5).

Lemma 1.

For any FL algorithm with the global model update scheme in (5), the loss decay in each iteration is upper bounded as follows:

≤\displaystyle\leq −ηt2​𝔼​[‖∇f​(𝐰t)‖2]−(ηt2−ηt2​L2)​‖𝔼​[𝐯t]‖2subscript𝜂𝑡2𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡2subscript𝜂𝑡2superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2𝐿2superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐯𝑡2\displaystyle-\frac{\eta_{t}}{2}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\|^{2}\right]-\left(\frac{\eta_{t}}{2}-\frac{\eta_{t}^{2}L}{2}\right)\left\|\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{v}_{t}]\right\|^{2}
+\displaystyle+ ηt2​L2​𝔼​[‖𝐯t−𝔼​[𝐯t]‖2]⏟Φt+ηt2​𝔼​[‖𝔼​[𝐯t]−∇f​(𝐰t)‖2]⏟ℰt.superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2𝐿2subscript⏟𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnormsubscript𝐯𝑡𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐯𝑡2subscriptΦ𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡2subscript⏟𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐯𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡2subscriptℰ𝑡\displaystyle\frac{\eta_{t}^{2}L}{2}\underbrace{\mathbb{E}\left[\|\mathbf{v}_{t}-\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{v}_{t}]\|^{2}\right]}_{\Phi_{t}}+\frac{\eta_{t}}{2}\underbrace{\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{v}_{t}]-\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\|^{2}\right]}_{\mathcal{E}_{t}}.
Proof.

Recall in (5) that 𝐰t+1=𝐰t−ηt​𝐯tsubscript𝐰𝑡1subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐯𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t+1}=\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta_{t}\mathbf{v}_{t} and accordingly f​(𝐰t+1)=f​(𝐰t−ηt​𝐯t)𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡1𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝜂𝑡subscript𝐯𝑡f(\mathbf{w}_{t+1})=f(\mathbf{w}_{t}-\eta_{t}\mathbf{v}_{t}). By leveraging the L𝐿L-smoothness of function f​(⋅)𝑓⋅f(\cdot) (i.e., Assumption 2), we have:

Remark 1.

Lemma 1 shows that the loss decay in each iteration is bounded by the weighted sum of ℰtsubscriptℰ𝑡\mathcal{E}_{t} and ΦtsubscriptΦ𝑡\Phi_{t}. For clarity, we use superscript FF\mathrm{F} and MM\mathrm{M} to represent these quantities in FedAvg and MimiC, respectively. As the values of ΦtsubscriptΦ𝑡\Phi_{t} and ℰtsubscriptℰ𝑡\mathcal{E}_{t} increase, the loss decay of each training iteration reduces, implying their negative effects on the convergence performance. Note that the term ΦtsubscriptΦ𝑡\Phi_{t} denotes the error caused by mini-batch data sampling, which is common in both FL and distributed training with SGD as the local training algorithm [40, 41]. Moreover, the term ℰtsubscriptℰ𝑡\mathcal{E}_{t} represents the gradient estimation error between the applied global update 𝐯tsubscript𝐯𝑡\mathbf{v}_{t} and the actual global gradient over all data samples ∇f​(𝐰t)∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t}).

We are now to provide an upper bound for the gradient estimation error ℰtsubscriptℰ𝑡\mathcal{E}_{t} in FedAvg. As will be shown later in Section 5, the value of ℰtsubscriptℰ𝑡\mathcal{E}_{t} serves as a key difference between FedAvg and our proposed algorithm.

If the local learning rate satisfies ηL≤110​Lsubscript𝜂𝐿110𝐿\eta_{L}\leq\frac{1}{10L}, the gradient estimation error ℰtFsuperscriptsubscriptℰ𝑡F\mathcal{E}_{t}^{\mathrm{F}} in FedAvg is upper bounded as follows:

Remark 2.

At the RHS of (14), the first term measures the initial error. The second and third terms are accumulated errors respectively caused by the mini-batching sampling and data heterogeneity. As aforementioned, these terms are common in the convergence bounds and cannot be mitigated in local SGD-based FL [42, 40]. Moreover, the term ΓTsubscriptΓ𝑇\Gamma_{T} represents the objective mismatch caused by client dropouts over the T𝑇T iterations.

Remark 3.

(Convergence of FedAvg) The common choice of the global learning rate in existing FL literature satisfies limT→∞∑t=0T−1ηt=∞subscript→Tsuperscriptsubscriptt0T1subscriptηt\lim_{T\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\eta_{t}=\infty, limT→∞∑t=0T−1ηt2<∞subscript→Tsuperscriptsubscriptt0T1superscriptsubscriptηt2\lim_{T\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\eta_{t}^{2}<\infty [37, 20, 43]. Notice that with such global learning rates, the RHS of (14) except the term ΓTsubscriptΓT\Gamma_{T} converges to zero as T→∞→TT\rightarrow\infty, implying that in the presence of arbitrary client dropout, FedAvg may only oscillate around a stationary point of the global loss function in the worst case. Nevertheless, there are still two obvious special cases where FedAvg can converge with client dropouts: 1) data among clients are IID (i.e., ∇f​(𝐰)≡∇fi​(𝐰),∀i∈𝒩formulae-sequence∇f𝐰∇subscriptfi𝐰for-alli𝒩\nabla f(\mathbf{w})\equiv\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}),\forall i\in\mathcal{N}); and 2) clients drop out with the same probability (ΓT=0subscriptΓT0\Gamma_{T}=0) [20, 19]. Unfortunately, none of these cases is practical in cross-device FL.

Since the objective mismatch ΓTsubscriptΓ𝑇\Gamma_{T} caused by arbitrary client dropouts cannot be eliminated by FedAvg, in order to mitigate its negative effects on model training, we propose a novel FL algorithm in the next section by modifying the update for each active client to mimic the imaginary central update.

5 Proposed Algorithm: MimiC

In this section, we propose the MimiC algorithm to mitigate the objective mismatch problem caused by client dropouts. Since each client has a distinctive local objective, we introduce a correction variable (denoted by 𝐜tisuperscriptsubscript𝐜𝑡𝑖\mathbf{c}_{t}^{i}) in MimiC to correct its local update such that the aggregated update is close to a desired central update ∇f​(𝐰t)∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t}). Note that ∇f​(𝐰t)=1N​∑i∈𝒩∇fi​(𝐰t)∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡1𝑁subscript𝑖𝒩∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t})=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{N}}\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}) represents an imaginary update over all training data based on the current model 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t}, which cannot be obtained with client dropouts. Specifically, once any client i𝑖i uploads the local update g^i​(𝐰t)subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}) successfully, the server modifies the received update as 𝐯ti≜g^i​(𝐰t)+𝐜ti≜superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑡𝑖subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐜𝑡𝑖\mathbf{v}_{t}^{i}\triangleq\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})+\mathbf{c}_{t}^{i}. The global update is computed as 𝐯t=1|𝒮t|​∑i∈𝒮t𝐯tisubscript𝐯𝑡1subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑡𝑖\mathbf{v}_{t}=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}_{t}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\mathbf{v}_{t}^{i} and applied to the global model according to (5). To ensure model convergence, the key is to design this correction variable properly.

Given the limited resources of clients in cross-device FL, we should avoid introducing additional computation or communication workload to them. Besides, since the server cannot perceive the client dropouts in advance, it is difficult to take preventative actions, e.g., assigning a higher training workload to a client that may become unavailable later. Therefore, we propose to exploit the gathered updates at the server by monitoring the training drifts in previous iterations. Assuming client i𝑖i is active in training iteration t𝑡t, the correction variable is defined as the drift from the current local update g^i​(𝐰t)subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}) to the applied global update 𝐯tsubscript𝐯𝑡\mathbf{v}_{t}, i.e.,

𝐜ti≜𝐯t−g^i​(𝐰t).≜superscriptsubscript𝐜𝑡𝑖subscript𝐯𝑡subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{c}_{t}^{i}\triangleq\mathbf{v}_{t}-\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}). (15)

The correction variable 𝐜tisuperscriptsubscript𝐜𝑡𝑖\mathbf{c}_{t}^{i} is updated if client i𝑖i is active in an iteration; otherwise it remains unchanged. In a later iteration, the server utilizes {𝐜ti}superscriptsubscript𝐜𝑡𝑖\{\mathbf{c}_{t}^{i}\}’s to correct the biased client updates. To summarize, the global update in iteration t𝑡t of MimiC is expressed as follows:

𝐯tsubscript𝐯𝑡\displaystyle\mathbf{v}_{t} ≜1|𝒮t|​∑i∈𝒮t(g^i​(𝐰t)+𝐜t−τ​(t,i)i)≜absent1subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐜𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖𝑖\displaystyle\triangleq\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}_{t}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\left(\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})+\mathbf{c}_{t-\tau(t,i)}^{i}\right)
=1|𝒮t|​∑i∈𝒮t(g^i​(𝐰t)−g^i​(𝐰t−τ​(t,i))+𝐯t−τ​(t,i)).absent1subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖subscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖\displaystyle=\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}_{t}|}\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\left(\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\hat{g}_{i}\left(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau(t,i)}\right)+\mathbf{v}_{t-\tau(t,i)}\right). (16)

The detailed training process of MimiC is summarized in Algorithm 1. We also show an example with four clients to illustrate the implementation of MimiC in Fig. 3, where two of them are available in the t𝑡t-th training iteration. Each active client uses its correction variable maintained from the latest active iteration t′=t−τ​(t,i)superscript𝑡′𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖t^{\prime}=t-\tau(t,i) to correct its local update. As a result, the aggregated update, i.e., the average of their corrected updates, is forced to mimic an imaginary central update and thus the global model is optimized towards the minimum of the global training objective.

To demonstrate the rationale of the proposed MimiC algorithm, we consider a simplified case with full-batch gradient descent as the local optimizer and assume one local step (K=1𝐾1K=1) in each training iteration, i.e., g^i​(𝐰t)≡∇fi​(𝐰t)subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})\equiv\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}). Denote Δ−i​(𝐰t)≜∇f​(𝐰t)−∇fi​(𝐰t)≜subscriptΔ𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\Delta_{-i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})\triangleq\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}). The modified update 𝐯tisuperscriptsubscript𝐯𝑡𝑖\mathbf{v}_{t}^{i} of an active client i𝑖i in iteration t𝑡t is expressed as follows:

𝐯tisuperscriptsubscript𝐯𝑡𝑖\displaystyle\mathbf{v}_{t}^{i} =∇fi​(𝐰t)−∇fi​(𝐰t−τ​(t,i))+𝐯t−τ​(t,i)absent∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖subscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖\displaystyle=\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\nabla f_{i}\left(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau(t,i)}\right)+\mathbf{v}_{t-\tau(t,i)}
=(a)​∇fi​(𝐰t)+[−∇fi​(𝐰t−τ​(t,i))+∇f​(𝐰t−τ​(t,i))]a∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡delimited-[]∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖\displaystyle\overset{(\text{a})}{=}\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})+\left[-\nabla f_{i}\left(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau(t,i)}\right)+\nabla f\left(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau(t,i)}\right)\right]
+[−∇f​(𝐰t−τ​(t,i))+𝐯t−τ​(t,i)]⏟A1subscript⏟delimited-[]∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖subscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖subscript𝐴1\displaystyle+\underbrace{[-\nabla f\left(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau(t,i)}\right)+\mathbf{v}_{t-\tau(t,i)}]}_{A_{1}}
=∇fi​(𝐰t)+A1+Δ−i​(𝐰t−τ​(t,i))absent∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐴1subscriptΔ𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖\displaystyle=\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})+A_{1}+\Delta_{-i}(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau(t,i)})

=(c)​∇f​(𝐰t)+A1+A2.c∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝐴1subscript𝐴2\displaystyle\overset{(\text{c})}{=}\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t})+A_{1}+A_{2}. (17)

In (a) of (17), the term A1subscript𝐴1A_{1} denotes the difference between ∇f​(𝐰t−τ​(t,i))∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖\nabla f\left(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau(t,i)}\right) and 𝐯t−τ​(t,i)subscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖\mathbf{v}_{t-\tau(t,i)} in the latest iteration t−τ​(t,i)𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖t-\tau(t,i) where client i𝑖i is active. We assume that all clients in the first training iteration are active, which, intuitively, ensures a high-quality approximation in training iteration t=0𝑡0t=0 and leads to small accumulated error in subsequent iterations (i.e., A1subscript𝐴1A_{1}) as well. The term A2subscript𝐴2A_{2} in (b) comes from the model difference in two iterations, i.e., 𝐰t−τ​(t,i)−𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau(t,i)}-\mathbf{w}_{t}, which is bounded via gradients and can be eliminated with a proper choice of the global learning rate. In addition, equation (c) follows the fact that Δ−i​(𝐰t)+∇fi​(𝐰t)=∇f​(𝐰t)subscriptΔ𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡∇subscript𝑓𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡\Delta_{-i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})+\nabla f_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})=\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t}). For the general case, the mini-batch gradients can be viewed as unbiased estimates of the full-batch gradient, while the effect of multiple local steps can also be bounded. Therefore, the applied update for each client mimics the central update. The above derivation also shows that ‖𝐯it−∇f​(𝐰t)‖22=‖A1+A2‖22superscriptsubscriptnormsuperscriptsubscript𝐯𝑖𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡22superscriptsubscriptnormsubscript𝐴1subscript𝐴222\left\|\mathbf{v}_{i}^{t}-\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\|_{2}^{2}=\left\|A_{1}+A_{2}\right\|_{2}^{2} is relatively stable. As will be shown in the next section, the proposed MimiC algorithm converges to a stationary point of the global loss function even with arbitrary client dropouts in cross-device FL.

Comparison with SCAFFOLD [38]. We notice that SCAFFOLD [38], a seminal algorithm for handling the non-IID issues in FL, also uses correction variables to modify the local updates. To be specific, SCAFFOLD extends a classic variance reduction technique named SAGA [44] to FL and modifies the client update in the k𝑘k-th local step as follows:

g^i​(𝐰t,ki)≜gi​(𝐰t,ki)−gi​(𝐰t)+1|𝒮t|​∑j∈𝒮tgj​(𝐰t).≜subscript^𝑔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘𝑖subscript𝑔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘𝑖subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡1subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑗subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑔𝑗subscript𝐰𝑡\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t,k}^{i})\triangleq g_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t,k}^{i})-g_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})+\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}_{t}|}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}g_{j}(\mathbf{w}_{t}). (18)

The local model 𝐰t,kisuperscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘𝑖\mathbf{w}_{t,k}^{i} is then updated using the modified update in (18). After K𝐾K local updating steps, each client uploads the accumulated model update ∑k=1Kg^i​(𝐰t,ki)superscriptsubscript𝑘1𝐾subscript^𝑔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘𝑖\sum_{k=1}^{K}\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t,k}^{i}) to the server for aggregation. In each training iteration, by correcting the local gradient gi​(𝐰t,ki)subscript𝑔𝑖superscriptsubscript𝐰𝑡𝑘𝑖g_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t,k}^{i}) using the update deviation evaluated with the initial model 𝐰tsubscript𝐰𝑡\mathbf{w}_{t} (i.e., 1|𝒮t|​∑j∈𝒮tgj​(𝐰t)−gi​(𝐰t)1subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑗subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑔𝑗subscript𝐰𝑡subscript𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}_{t}|}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}g_{j}(\mathbf{w}_{t})-g_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})), the modified update in (18) alleviates the negative effect of biased local updates. However, the theoretical convergence guarantee of SCAFFOLD requires 𝔼​[1|𝒮t|​∑j∈𝒮tgj​(𝐰t)]=1N​∑j∈𝒩gj​(𝐰t)𝔼delimited-[]1subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑗subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑔𝑗subscript𝐰𝑡1𝑁subscript𝑗𝒩subscript𝑔𝑗subscript𝐰𝑡\mathbb{E}\left[\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}_{t}|}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}g_{j}(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right]=\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}g_{j}(\mathbf{w}_{t}) and only holds with uniform client participation. In comparison, MimiC aims to correct the training bias caused by both client dropout and data heterogeneity. Such a bias is encoded in the difference between the local update and the sum of model updates from all clients (i.e., 1N​∑j∈𝒩∇fj​(𝐰t)−g^i​(𝐰t)1𝑁subscript𝑗𝒩∇subscript𝑓𝑗subscript𝐰𝑡subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\frac{1}{N}\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}\nabla f_{j}(\mathbf{w}_{t})-\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})), which, however, is not accessible due to client dropouts. Hence, we propose to use 𝐜t−τ​(t,i)i=𝐯t−τ​(t,i)−g^i​(𝐰t−τ​(t,i))superscriptsubscript𝐜𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖𝑖subscript𝐯𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖\mathbf{c}_{t-\tau(t,i)}^{i}=\mathbf{v}_{t-\tau(t,i)}-\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau(t,i)}) from iteration t−τ​(t,i)𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖t-\tau(t,i) where client i𝑖i was last active to correct the local update. We demonstrate the superior performance of MimiC compared with SCAFFOLD in Section 7.

Practical implementations. If there are a large number of clients, the proposed MimiC algorithm can be implemented in an alternative way to amortize the computation and memory overhead at the server, where the clients correct their gradient updates locally and upload the modified gradients. To be specific, each client stores a local correction variable 𝐜t′i=𝐯t′−g^i​(𝐰t′)superscriptsubscript𝐜superscript𝑡′𝑖subscript𝐯superscript𝑡′subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰superscript𝑡′\mathbf{c}_{t^{\prime}}^{i}=\mathbf{v}_{t^{\prime}}-\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t^{\prime}}) after an active iteration t′superscript𝑡′t^{\prime}. In the next active iteration t𝑡t, client i𝑖i computes gradient g^i​(𝐰t)subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t}) and upload the corrected update 𝐯ti=g^i​(𝐰t)+𝐜t′isuperscriptsubscript𝐯𝑡𝑖subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐜superscript𝑡′𝑖\mathbf{v}_{t}^{i}=\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t})+\mathbf{c}_{{t^{\prime}}}^{i} to the server for aggregation. In this way, compared with FedAvg, each client only needs to store one more variable 𝐜t′isuperscriptsubscript𝐜superscript𝑡′𝑖\mathbf{c}_{{t^{\prime}}}^{i} with the same dimension as the model gradient and there is no additional computation and memory requirement at the server. Notably, as the server only requires a sum ∑i∈𝒮t𝐯tisubscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑡𝑖\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\mathbf{v}_{t}^{i}, secure aggregation techniques [45, 46] can be further implemented to preserve the privacy of local models.

6 Convergence of MimiC

In this section, we analyze the convergence performance of MimiC. Similar to the analysis in Section 4, we first derive an upper bound of the gradient estimation error ℰt≜𝔼​[‖𝔼​[𝐯t]−∇f​(𝐰t)‖2]≜subscriptℰ𝑡𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]subscript𝐯𝑡∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡2\mathcal{E}_{t}\triangleq\mathbb{E}[\left\|\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{v}_{t}]-\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\|^{2}] in the following lemma.

Lemma 4.

If the global learning rates satisfy:

there exists an arbitrarily small positive constant ν>0𝜈0\nu>0 such that the gradient estimation error ℰtMsuperscriptsubscriptℰ𝑡M\mathcal{E}_{t}^{\mathrm{M}} in MimiC can be upper bounded as follows:

Proof Sketch.

We first utilize the Cauchy–Schwarz inequality to show

ℰtM≤1|𝒮t|​∑i∈𝒮t𝔼​[‖𝔼​[𝐯ti]−∇f​(𝐰t)‖2].superscriptsubscriptℰ𝑡M1subscript𝒮𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑡𝑖∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡2\displaystyle\mathcal{E}_{t}^{\mathrm{M}}\leq\frac{1}{|\mathcal{S}_{t}|}\!\sum_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\mathbb{E}\left[\left\|\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{v}_{t}^{i}]-\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\|^{2}\right]. (21)

Afterwards, we respectively upper bound the estimation error between 𝔼​[𝐯ti]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑡𝑖\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{v}_{t}^{i}] and ∇f​(𝐰t)∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t}) for each client in 𝒮tsubscript𝒮𝑡\mathcal{S}_{t} and sum these error bounds up. The main challenge is that 𝔼​[𝐯ti]𝔼delimited-[]superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑡𝑖\mathbb{E}[\mathbf{v}_{t}^{i}] and ∇f​(𝐰t)∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t}) are not directly related. To connect these terms, we resort to the intermediate terms ∇f​(𝐰t−τ​(t,i))∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau(t,i)}) and 𝔼​[g^i​(𝐰t−τ​(t,i))]𝔼delimited-[]subscript^𝑔𝑖subscript𝐰𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖\mathbb{E}[\hat{g}_{i}(\mathbf{w}_{t-\tau(t,i)})]. We then use the fact that ‖𝐱+𝐲‖2≤(1+α)​‖𝐱‖2+(1+1α)​‖𝐲‖2,∀α>0formulae-sequencesuperscriptnorm𝐱𝐲21𝛼superscriptnorm𝐱211𝛼superscriptnorm𝐲2for-all𝛼0\|\mathbf{x}+\mathbf{y}\|^{2}\leq(1+\alpha)\|\mathbf{x}\|^{2}+(1+\frac{1}{\alpha})\|\mathbf{y}\|^{2},\forall\alpha>0 with α=αt𝛼subscript𝛼𝑡\alpha=\alpha_{t} and α=1𝛼1\alpha=1 sequentially. Note that to make αt>0subscript𝛼𝑡0\alpha_{t}>0, the condition in (19) is required, which can be satisfied by properly adapting the global learning rates. Thereafter, an upper bound of ℰtMsuperscriptsubscriptℰ𝑡M\mathcal{E}_{t}^{\mathrm{M}} can be decomposed as follows:

Please refer to Appendix C for the detailed proof. ∎

Remark 4.

As will be shown in Theorem 2, the terms on the RHS of (20) can be eliminated by using proper learning rates. By comparing the upper bounds of ℰtFsuperscriptsubscriptℰ𝑡F\mathcal{E}_{t}^{\mathrm{F}} in Lemma 2 and ℰtMsuperscriptsubscriptℰ𝑡M\mathcal{E}_{t}^{\mathrm{M}} in Lemma 4, it can be noticed that the term γtsubscript𝛾𝑡\gamma_{t} caused by arbitrary client dropouts in FedAvg is eliminated in MimiC. This is because the correction variables {𝐜ti}superscriptsubscript𝐜𝑡𝑖\{\mathbf{c}_{t}^{i}\}’s enforce the applied updates {𝐯ti}superscriptsubscript𝐯𝑡𝑖\{\mathbf{v}_{t}^{i}\}’s to mimic the central update ∇f​(𝐰t)∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t}) with a bounded divergence. With a proper choice of the learning rates, the corresponding objective mismatch can also be eliminated.

Before presenting the convergence result of MimiC, we show the existence of the global learning rates specified in Theorem 2 via the following lemma.

Lemma 6.

There exists a set of global learning rates {ηt}t=0T−1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡𝑡0𝑇1\{\eta_{t}\}_{t=0}^{T-1} that satisfies the conditions in Theorem 2 (i.e., (19) and (25)), and limT→∞∑t=0T−1ηt=∞subscript→𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1subscript𝜂𝑡\lim_{T\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\eta_{t}=\infty, limT→∞∑t=0T−1ηt2<∞subscript→𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2\lim_{T\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\eta_{t}^{2}<\infty.

Proof Sketch.

The proof can be obtained by constructing ηt=c​|𝒮t|t+βsubscript𝜂𝑡𝑐subscript𝒮𝑡𝑡𝛽\eta_{t}=\frac{c|\mathcal{S}_{t}|}{t+\beta}, where c𝑐c and β𝛽\beta are positive constants. We show that there exists c>0𝑐0c>0 such that all the assumptions of {ηt}t=0T−1superscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡𝑡0𝑇1\{\eta_{t}\}_{t=0}^{T-1} can be simultaneously satisfied. Please refer to Appendix E for the detailed proof. ∎

With the results in Theorem 2 and Lemma 6, we show the convergence of MimiC in the following corollary, and the proof is deferred to Appendix F.

Corollary 1.

If the learning rates satisfy ηL=𝒪​(1L​T)subscript𝜂𝐿𝒪1𝐿𝑇\eta_{L}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{L\sqrt{T}}\right), the conditions in Theorem 2, and limT→∞∑t=0T−1ηt=∞subscript→𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1subscript𝜂𝑡\lim_{T\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\eta_{t}=\infty, limT→∞∑t=0T−1ηt2<∞subscript→𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2\lim_{T\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\eta_{t}^{2}<\infty, the RHS of (26) converges to zero as T→∞→𝑇T\rightarrow\infty, i.e., MimiC converges to a stationary point of the global loss function.

The above results show the superiority of MimiC over FedAvg in the presence of random client dropouts. By correcting the local updates, MimiC can ensure convergence, while FedAvg may only arrive at a solution around a stationary point of the global loss function. While the convergence of MimiC does not require a certain regime of τmaxsubscript𝜏max\tau_{\text{max}}, a large value does have a negative impact on the convergence behavior. In particular, the learning rate needs to be reduced to ensure model convergence, and the convergence time may be prolonged significantly.

In some cases, clients become active with certain probabilities in each training iteration instead of having bounded dropout iterations. The active probability of a client may be determined by various factors, e.g., the communication link quality and local computation workloads. For example, clients such as Unmanned Aerial Vehicles (UAVs) can fly away from the server at any training iteration [47], and the change of path loss results in different active probabilities. In the following, we show the convergence of MimiC under probabilistic client dropout as specified in Assumption 5.

Assumption 5.

Client i∈𝒩𝑖𝒩i\in\mathcal{N} becomes active with probability pti∈(0,1]superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑡𝑖01p_{t}^{i}\in(0,1] in the t𝑡t-th training iteration.

Theorem 3.

With Assumptions 2-3 and 5, if learning rates {ηt}t=0Tsuperscriptsubscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡𝑡0𝑇\{\eta_{t}\}_{t=0}^{T} satisfy ρt>1subscript𝜌𝑡1\rho_{t}>1 and 1ηt​(12​ηt−L2)≥(ρt−ν)​φK​τ~​(t)​N2​ν​|𝒮t|1subscript𝜂𝑡12subscript𝜂𝑡𝐿2subscript𝜌𝑡𝜈subscript𝜑𝐾~𝜏𝑡𝑁2𝜈subscript𝒮𝑡\frac{1}{\eta_{t}}\left(\frac{1}{2\eta_{t}}-\frac{L}{2}\right)\geq\frac{(\rho_{t}-\nu)\varphi_{K}\tilde{\tau}(t)N}{2\nu|\mathcal{S}_{t}|}, then for arbitrary δ∈(0,1)𝛿01\delta\in(0,1), we have:

1∑t=0T−1ηt​∑t=0T−1ηt​𝔼​[‖∇f​(𝐰t)‖2]1superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1subscript𝜂𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1subscript𝜂𝑡𝔼delimited-[]superscriptnorm∇𝑓subscript𝐰𝑡2\displaystyle\frac{1}{\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\eta_{t}}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\eta_{t}\mathbb{E}[\left\|\nabla f(\mathbf{w}_{t})\right\|^{2}]
≤\displaystyle\leq 2​Δ∑t=0T−1ηt+2∑t=0T−1ηt∑t=0T−1σ2|𝒮t|​K[ηt2​L2\displaystyle\frac{2\Delta}{\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\eta_{t}}+\frac{2}{\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\eta_{t}}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\frac{\sigma^{2}}{|\mathcal{S}_{t}|K}\left[\frac{\eta_{t}^{2}L}{2}\right.
+\displaystyle+ ρt​(ρt−ν)​ηt​φKν​(ρt−1−ν)​(mini⁡pti)2(log(N​tδ)+1)2ηt+12|𝒮t+1|],\displaystyle\left.\frac{\rho_{t}(\rho_{t}-\nu)\eta_{t}\varphi_{K}}{\nu(\rho_{t}-1-\nu)(\min_{i}p_{t}^{i})^{2}}\left(\log\left(\frac{Nt}{\delta}\right)+1\right)^{2}\frac{\eta_{t+1}^{2}}{|\mathcal{S}_{t+1}|}\right], (29)

with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta, where τ~​(t)≜maxi∈𝒮t⁡τ​(t,i)≜~𝜏𝑡subscript𝑖subscript𝒮𝑡𝜏𝑡𝑖\tilde{\tau}(t)\triangleq\max_{i\in\mathcal{S}_{t}}\tau(t,i).

Proof Sketch.

We obtain the result with a similar proof of Theorem 2, where the gradient estimation error ℰtMsuperscriptsubscriptℰ𝑡M\mathcal{E}_{t}^{\mathrm{M}} is expressed in terms of τ~​(t)~𝜏𝑡\tilde{\tau}(t). We then show τ~​(t)~𝜏𝑡\tilde{\tau}(t) can be upper bounded using {pit}superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖𝑡\{p_{i}^{t}\}’s with a high probability. Please refer to Appendix G for the detailed proof. ∎

The following corollary shows the convergence result of MimiC under probabilistic client dropout, and the proof is deferred to Appendix H.

Corollary 2.

If the learning rates satisfy ηL=𝒪​(1L​T)subscript𝜂𝐿𝒪1𝐿𝑇\eta_{L}=\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{L\sqrt{T}}\right), the conditions in Theorem 2, and limT→∞∑t=0T−1ηt=∞subscript→𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1subscript𝜂𝑡\lim_{T\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\eta_{t}=\infty, limT→∞∑t=0T−1ηt2<∞subscript→𝑇superscriptsubscript𝑡0𝑇1superscriptsubscript𝜂𝑡2\lim_{T\rightarrow\infty}\sum_{t=0}^{T-1}\eta_{t}^{2}<\infty, the RHS of (29) converges to zero as T→∞→𝑇T\rightarrow\infty. This guarantees that MimiC converges to a stationary point of the global loss function with a high probability under probabilistic client dropout.

The conventional FL algorithms are hard to ensure convergence in the critical scenario with arbitrary client dropouts. To preserve model convergence in this scenario, existing methods [23, 22] utilize the memorized latest updates as a substitute for those dropout clients, which suffers from the staleness of local updates. In contrast, our proposed method MimiC corrects the local updates by mimicking an imaginary central update. By doing so, we can achieve substantial training performance improvement as verified by the simulation results in Section 7, in additional to the theoretical convergence guarantee.

7 Performance Evaluation

7.1 Settings

We simulate a cross-device FL system with one central server and N=30𝑁30N=30 clients. To comprehensively demonstrate the effects of client dropouts, we simulate three scenarios with different client availability patterns, including:

  1. 1.

    Clients have bounded consecutive dropout iterations [22]: Each client becomes active every τmax​(i)subscript𝜏max𝑖\tau_{\text{max}}(i) iterations in a round-robin fashion, where τmax​(i)subscript𝜏max𝑖\tau_{\text{max}}(i) is uniformly sampled from [0,τmax]0subscript𝜏max[0,\tau_{\text{max}}].

  2. 2.

    Clients have static active probabilities [23]: All clients have the same and fixed active probability. In iteration t𝑡t, a random number rti∈[0,1]superscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑖01r_{t}^{i}\in[0,1] is uniformly generated for the i𝑖i-th client. The client is active if rtisuperscriptsubscript𝑟𝑡𝑖r_{t}^{i} is no larger than its active probability; otherwise it drops out of training in this iteration.

  3. 3.

    Clients have time-varying active probabilities [2, 48]: In iteration t𝑡t, each client randomly generates a weight ati∈[1,10]superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑡𝑖110a_{t}^{i}\in[1,10], of which, a large value implies higher likelihood to become active. We determine P×N𝑃𝑁P\times N active clients in simulations by sampling clients without replacement using probability vector [at1,⋯,atN]/∑j∈𝒩atjsuperscriptsubscript𝑎𝑡1⋯superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑡𝑁subscript𝑗𝒩superscriptsubscript𝑎𝑡𝑗[a_{t}^{1},\cdots,a_{t}^{N}]/\sum_{j\in\mathcal{N}}a_{t}^{j}, where P∈[0,1]𝑃01P\in\left[0,1\right] is a predefined ratio.

For comparisons, we adopt FedAvg [1], FedProx [37], SCAFFOLD [38], and MIFA [23] as baseline algorithms. In MIFA, the server stores the latest model update for each client and uses it for aggregation in case of client dropout. Other algorithms are benchmark FL training algorithms but not specialized for combating client dropouts. It is also worth noting that SCAFFOLD requires each client to upload two updated variables and thus incurs double communication cost in each training iteration compared with other methods. Hence, we evaluate the accuracy of different algorithms on the test dataset with respect to the same amount of communication costs (i.e., the number of model uploadings) for fair comparisons. Table I summarizes the main characteristics of these algorithms.

We evaluate these algorithms on two benchmark image datasets, including the FMNIST [49] and CIFAR-10 [50] datasets. Both datasets have ten classes of labels. The training datasets of FMNIST and CIFAR-10 respectively have 60,000 and 50,000 data samples in total, which are assigned to 30 clients in equal size. To simulate the non-IID setting, we divide the training dataset into 60 shards, each of which includes one random class of data samples, and assign two random shards to each client. In the FMNIST training task, we adopt a convolutional neural network (CNN) model [51], which has two 5×5555\times 5 convolutional layers followed by 2×2222\times 2 max pooling layers and two fully connected layers with ReLU activation, while a VGG-11 model [52] is adopted in the CIFAR-10 training task. The detailed experimental setup are summarized in Table II. Under the above setup, FedAvg without client dropout can achieve accuracy of 76.82%percent76.8276.82\% and 62.48%percent62.4862.48\% after 200 and 400 model uploadings on the FMNIST and CIFAR10 datasets, respectively.

7.2 Results

We first consider the scenario where clients have bounded consecutive dropout iterations, i.e., τ​(t,i)≤τmax𝜏𝑡𝑖subscript𝜏max\tau(t,i)\leq\tau_{\text{max}}. We assume τmax=20subscript𝜏max20\tau_{\text{max}}=20 and show the test accuracy of different algorithms on the FMNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets in Fig. 4 and Fig. 5, respectively. We observe that the test accuracy of FedAvg, FedProx, and SCAFFOLD suffer from different degrees of oscillation over training iterations due to drastic alternation of active clients, which is more obvious in the harder CIFAR-10 training task. This is because these algorithms lack a dedicated mechanism to deal with random client dropouts. In contrast, MimiC and MIFA avoid this issue via different client dropout mitigating strategies and thus converge to better global models. Compared with MIFA, MimiC achieves both improved model accuracy and training efficiency since it effectively corrects the received updates to mimic an imaginary central update.

We also vary τmaxsubscript𝜏max\tau_{\text{max}} and show the test accuracy of different algorithms on the FMNIST dataset after 200 model uploadings in Table III. It is seen that as the value of τmaxsubscript𝜏max\tau_{\text{max}} increases, the test accuracy of all FL algorithms decreases due to more severe client dropouts. Nevertheless, both MIFA and MimiC suffer from comparatively less performance degradation, again validating their effectiveness in combating client dropouts. Notably, MimiC consistently outperforms all the baselines with the given communication cost.

Moreover, we evaluate the performance of MimiC, MIFA, and FedAvg on the FMNIST training task by varying the static active probability p𝑝p. As shown in Fig. 6, when clients have larger active probabilities, the test accuracy of the learned model increases as more informative gradients are collected. However, uploading more gradients means more communication costs, verifying the trade-off between the model accuracy and communication cost. In all cases, MimiC consistently outperforms the baselines since it mitigates the negative impacts of client dropout via effective model update correction.

Next, we investigate the scenario where clients become active in each iteration with a static probability. In particular, the active probability is set as 0.10.10.1 and 0.30.30.3 for the FMNIST and CIFAR-10 training task, as respectively shown in Figs. 7 and 8. Compared with the first scenario, the assumption of client availability is much relaxed. However, most FL algorithms still show unstable convergence behavior because of low client availability. Similar to the observations in Figs. 4 and 5, both MIFA and MimiC effectively mitigate the negative effects of client dropout, and MimiC converges to a more accurate model with a faster speed. In addition, we see that SCAFFOLD may fail to converge in the difficult CIFAR-10 training task, as shown in Figs. 5 and 8, since it suffers from the accumulated gradient estimation error caused by the client dropout.

In addition, we simulate the scenario where clients have time-varying dropout probabilities, which are randomly generated in each iteration with parameter P𝑃P denoting the ratio of active clients in each iteration. Table IV shows the test accuracy on the FMNIST and CIFAR-10 datasets. In general, all methods achieve higher test accuracy as the value of P𝑃P increases, i.e., more clients are active in each iteration. Similar to the previous scenarios, MimiC consistently outperforms other algorithms with different levels of client availability. In particular, when the participation ratio is very low, i.e., P=10%𝑃percent10P=10\%, MimiC achieves noticeable accuracy improvement compared to all baselines. These results clearly demonstrate the effectiveness of MimiC in combating client dropouts in cross-device FL systems.

Finally, we study the impact of data heterogeneity on the training performance in Table V, where we vary the number of classes of data samples on each client to simulate different degrees of data heterogeneity. We see that more classes of data samples at each client, i.e., a lower level of data heterogeneity, can lead to a faster training speed due to a smaller objective mismatch. When each client has 888 or 101010 classes of data samples, different algorithms achieve similar model accuracy. This is because clients have almost IID data and the missing model updates of dropout clients can be easily compensated by those of the active clients. In all cases, MimiC learns better models than the baselines methods as it alleviates the objective mismatch due to clients dropouts by appropriately correcting the local updates.

8 Conclusions

In this paper, we investigated the cross-device federated learning in the presence of arbitrary client dropouts. We first proved that in this critical scenario, the classical FedAvg algorithm is not guaranteed to converge with the common choice of a decaying learning rate. This unsatisfactory performance motivated the design of a new federated learning algorithm named MimiC, where each applied update is corrected via previous updates to mimic the imaginary central update without needing the client availability pattern. We showed that with a proper choice of the learning rates, MimiC converges to a stationary point of the global loss function. The extensive simulations demonstrated that MimiC consistently outperforms the baselines in various scenarios, in addition to having the theoretical convergence guarantee. For future work, it is worth investigating how to fuse the staleness-aware model aggregation schemes with MimiC to further improve its training performance.

Appendix F Proof of Corollary 1

In order to show the convergence, the key is to prove with the selected learning rates, the RHS of (26) diminishes to zero with a high probability.
